data.title: BBC Local Live: Updates from North East England on Monday 18 July 2016
data.meta_description: Bringing you the latest news, sport, travel and weather from across the North East on Monday 18 July 2016.
data.text:
The sentencing hearing in the case of two girls who kidnapped a toddler in Primark in Newcastle has heard how the girls initially enticed another youngster away from her mother in the same store.

CCTV footage showed to Newcastle Crown Court showed how they were "leading her round the store by the hand" away from the view of her mum.

But the woman managed to find her daughter and believed the two teenagers had been helping the child.

Prosecutor in the case, Sarah Barlow, is now beginning to outline the case against the two girls who kidnapped a toddler from Newcastle's Primark store on 13 April.

She told Newcastle Crown Court the girls had skipped school that day and travelled to to the city centre by Metro.

They were in Primark between 09:00 and 09.45.

From there they went to Boots' child clothing section.

The crown says that the trip to Boots supports its case that the kidnap was planned.

They returned to Primark for the majority of the morning, where they spent time in the children's clothing department.

The sentencing hearing of two girls who kidnapped a toddler from a Newcastle store has reconvened.

The court has been told by defence barrister Andrew Walker that the older girl has indicated she is not willing to give evidence as part of a Newton Hearing due to be held this morning.

It comes after the sentencing hearing at Newcastle Crown Court was earlier told there are issues over the basis on which the girls are to be sentenced.

The girl has asked for her written statement to be accepted as a truthful account of what happened on the day of the kidnap in April.

The younger girl's barrister, Julia Clemitson, says her client does not want to give evidence either today and wishes to rely on her previously submitted statement.

A Teesside man has described how helicopters landed outside his hotel and gunmen opened fire, destroying his glass balcony during an attempted coup in Turkey.

Alan Carter had just arrived in the resort of Marmaris when the attempted coup happened.

He said: "There were screams and shouts in the corridor outside our room, and then there were gunshots in the corridor as well, so we were sandwiched between two bouts of shooting."

"it was a very unnerving time, we wrapped ourselves up in a mattress, did the usual things, huddled together in a corner and kept out of the way the best we could."

The Foreign Office has relaxed its advice for British people travelling to Turkey - although it says they should still avoid public places in Ankara and Istanbul, particularly demonstrations.

AFPCopyright: AFP

Two teenage girls who snatched a toddler from the Primark shop in Newcastle city centre are back in court this morning and are due to be sentenced.

The girls, aged 14 and 13, previously pleaded guilty to kidnapping the youngster in April.

The pair, who cannot be named because of their age, were found in Gosforth with the child about one hour and 45 minutes after enticing her from the store with sweets.

Although they have admitted kidnap, the court has this morning heard there are significant differences between the defence and prosecution about the basis on which they will be sentenced.

Following discussions about whether one of the girls will give evidence in court or via video link, proceedings are at a halt.

Peter Barron, the voice of BBC Tees' Headline Challenge and occasional presenter, has accepted a role at Middlesbrough College.

From September, the former Northern Echo editor will work as part of the media department, focusing on print-based journalism.

Peter said he was delighted to be playing a role in training the journalists of tomorrow, adding: “I was just a young lad from South Bank in Middlesbrough, but journalism took me to being editor of one of the biggest regional newspapers in the country and being given an MBE."

PETER BARRONCopyright: PETER BARRON

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has paid tribute to Durham Miners' Gala secretary Dave Hopper, who has died.

His death on Saturday came one week after he shared a platform with Mr Corbyn at the 132nd gala - one of Europe's largest trade union events, also known as the Big Meeting.

Mr Corbyn said Mr Hopper was "a pillar of strength for the working class".

Mr Hopper had backed Mr Corbyn to retain control in the Labour leadership contest.

BBCCopyright: BBC

His discovery of a young Jimi Hendrix in a New York club would change the face of music forever. Twenty years on from Chas Chandler's death, those who knew him look back at his life.

Summer 1966. A small Greenwich Village venue. There, a little-known guitarist performing under the stage-name Jimmy James would set in motion a four-year chain of events destined to go down among the most famous in rock 'n' roll folklore.

Sitting among the Cafe Wha? audience, on the recommendation of Stones guitarist Keith Richards' girlfriend, was Bryan "Chas" Chandler - bassist with chart-topping UK band The Animals and now on the lookout for new talent to guide through the murky world of the music business.

"This guy didn't seem anything special, then all of a sudden he started playing with his teeth," recalls roadie James "Tappy" Wright, who was alongside his long-time pal and fellow Geordie.

Read the full feature here.

Labour's Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell is giving a speech at the Sunderland Glass Centre committing his party to a Bank for the North to invest in the region.

He tells the audience that the Brexit vote was a rejection of the economic model of austerity.

BBCCopyright: BBC

He adds the government must act now to show how it'll protect North East trade links and replace EU funding.

Stockton South Conservative MP James Wharton is no longer minister for the Northern Powerhouse.

He's been moved to become a junior minister in International Development.

His old job has now been taken over by Andrew Percy, MP for Brigg and Goole in East Yorkshire.

However Mr Percy's official title no longer mentions the Northern Powerhouse - officially he is Under Secretary of State at the Department for Communities and Local Government.

A government spokesman said the Northern Powerhouse "will continue to be a priority".

Mr Percy said he was "keen to give this role my best shot".

BBCCopyright: BBC

A County Durham museum has reached its £1m fundraising target.

Bowed Museum was awarded a Catalyst Endowments programme grant four years' ago with the proviso it matched the money pound-for-pound.

With the deadline this month, there have been more than 800 individual donors from as far afield as Australia, as well as contributions from visitors.

The museum said it was extremely pleased to have raised the money within the allotted time frame.

GoogleCopyright: Google

Malaysia Airlines has settled damages with the relatives of most victims of the MH17 crash, the lawyer representing the victims, Veeru Mewa, says.

Flight MH17 was shot down exactly two years ago over territory held by pro-Russian separatists, killing all 298 people on board, most of them Dutch.

Under the Montreal Convention, which regulates air travel, airlines must pay damages of up to about $145,000 (£109,000) to victims' families, regardless of the circumstances of a crash.

Two Newcastle fans were killed in the plane crash.

The father of one of the victims of flight MH17 said he had to believe those on board died quickly or it would 'hurt forever'.

ReutersCopyright: Reuters

Two girls aged 13 and 14 who used sweets to entice a toddler away from her mother while she shopped in a Primark store in Newcastle will be sentenced today.

The girls were to be sentenced on Friday but their case was adjourned until today

Their victim was the second child they intended to grab from the store, having tried unsuccessfully to trick another little girl's mother.

In both cases they picked on black children.

Alarming internet searches about "rape" were also found on a tablet computer, it emerged.

We will bring you more updates as we get them.

PACopyright: PA
